title: Shadow and Fortune: Chapter One

embed.description: With the fall of Gangplank, Bilgewater descends into chaos as old rivalries are settled in blood while gang warfare threatens to tear the city apart. Miss Fortune counts the cost of her vengeance as the Black Mist rolls out of the Shadow Isles to engulf the city in a nightmare storm of restless dead.

body:
It's here folks! Beware the Harrowing! Take a read and enjoy!

Also included is Kalista's long lore, complete with the Invocation short!

{{champion:2}}: WHY WON'T I DIE!?

The problem I have with the lore is that it is way too long and spells out everything. No one cares about Karthus as a child -- they care about what he is now. A single sentence or two about his past would have been fine. Shortening the stories down to 1/3rd or 1/4th of what they are would have done wonders.

We get it, you want to flesh out the world, but so many times in storytelling the old adage is still true: "less is more." Leave some to the imagination, give hints to the full story, don't just state it all out.
Hush, some people actually like these little details and quite enjoy delving into the pasts of our most beloved champs.

Personally I like to understand why my character acts the way they do. For those that don't care, they don't have to read it, but for those of us that want to understand a character's psyche a little better, it's nice to have.

Exactly my point.
Why cater to those who don't even "like" lore?
That's why the client lore's pretty much only a fourth of the extended lore, to give some people a rough understanding of the champion's background.
If it sparks a flame of interest one can quickly find a well laid-out format of one's favorite champion.

It's honestly one of the best possible solutions.

Rather than force things down your throat and making super intimidating walls of text from the get-go, Riot's leaving the door open and saying "Hey, if you want, you can come in and join us!". Only THEN do they give you the walls of text, those glorious, glorious walls of text!

Ahh... We should build a shrine to those texts.
A real Wonderwall for us to worship!
10/10 would bow before the glory of the Wonderwordwall.

Except having everything spelled out removes a lot of mystery and eloquence. Do you want a story where every single thing is told? That is boring.

Good story telling knows what to leave out. These tales are way too over complicated. Who cares that Karthus's mom died during childbirth and he was raised with his father? That doesn't matter in his current development.

Little details like these will explain the character though. It gives us insight in who he is. Also the Shadow Isles have had a lot of speculation and mystery around them already. Everything being a mystery is also boring.

Well done mystery is not boring. If they know how to hint at things and leave subtle clues it is intriguing. Instead it is just way too drawn out. What are we going to have next? Karthus's childhood diary entries? Mordekaiser's dinner plans? Kalista's favorite colors in order?

There are amazing settings that paint huge pictures while being vague about things. Look at the Planescape setting in D&D as an example. They explain a lot, but leave so much out, with subtle clues given here and there. That is good world building. Instead we get seemingly direct accounts about the childhood of people -- how does anyone know that who is still living? How is it not just rumor and speculation instead of stated fact? Just seems like poor writing and story telling to me.

Consider this the reveal afterwards. All mysteries with no reveals gets tedious. It would actually suggest the writers not knowing what the answer is when they make the mystery. It's a good way to lose fans.

We currently are in a world-building stage again. The whole old world is retconned, the new one is being treated as a blank slate. You need a base to speculate from.

There's enough champion backgrounds that're vague and mysterious. It gets repetitive and can easily make the champions feel distant, even though we directly play them in the game and they're the main focus of things.

***

Mystery is fun. But there's a time and a place for it. Incidentally, have you read the Journals of Justice? They did quite a couple of mysteries I believe.

Congratulations to Bioluminescence, the dead canary in your survival kit made into lore.

That said, spooky stuff. Too spooky, perhaps; I'm ready to visit someplace a little less grimdark than Bilgewater now. Seventeen dead is just a slow evening, fishing grubs pulled from a corpse's sockets, men hung by a skewer in their jaw? 

Nope. I'm good.

Let's go someplace nice, like... Ionia? No, that's occupied by Noxus. Demacia? No, no... I'd hate to be hung for jaywalking. Nox- Hah, no. Shurima? Not bad, but the neighbors in Icathia aren't so accommodating. Freljord? Stuck in a civil war, but at least they have Braum. Zaun? Eh... I'd rather not donate my body to science while I'm still living. Plague Jungles? Not with a name like that. Mount Targon? I don't like hiking.

Piltover? {{champion:222}} 

You know what, forget it.
